title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 14
author: Various
snippet: "Yes, sir, Raeburn is no more--his villanous career is ended.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 14
author: Various
snippet: "Raise your weapon, Raeburn; raise your weapon!" exclaimed Rutherford,on observing that his antagonist was not proceeding to assume a hostileattitude.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 14
author: Various
snippet: Although you but little deserve it, I willgive you a chance for your life! Come, sir," he went on, Raeburndeclining to take the pistol, "take it--take it; for, by the heavenabove us, one or other of us, or both, must die; and your only chanceis in opposing me; for, if you do not fire, I will! By all that'ssacred, I will!" At this moment, Raeburn rushed to the window, with theview of calling for assistance; and one supplicatory cry, which,however, was unattended to, he did emit.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 14
author: Various
snippet: Although you but little deserve it, I willgive you a chance for your life! Come, sir," he went on, Raeburndeclining to take the pistol, "take it--take it; for, by the heavenabove us, one or other of us, or both, must die; and your only chanceis in opposing me; for, if you do not fire, I will! By all that'ssacred, I will!" At this moment, Raeburn rushed to the window, with theview of calling for assistance; and one supplicatory cry, which,however, was unattended to, he did emit.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 14
author: Various
snippet: One evening, about nine o'clock, Raeburn was sitting solitary in hisroom, musing on the miseries to which his villany had subjected him, andno doubt indulging, as all villains do, in imaginary schemes ofvengeance against his enemies, when a waiter from one of the hotels intown called, and said that a gentleman there desired to see himimmediately on a matter of importance.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 14
author: Various
snippet: Neither would he suffer him to interfere in any way whateverwith the funeral rites; the whole expense of which he insisted on payingout of his own pocket; and Raeburn knew too well the advantage thedoctor possessed over him, to offer any resistance to these peremptoryobjections.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 14
author: Various
snippet: After Fanny's death, Raeburn had evinced a disposition to take an activepart in her obsequies; and even expressed a willingness to defray thewhole of the funeral charges.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 14
author: Various
snippet: "Ruffian, sir!" repeated Raeburn, affecting to feel insulted, althoughhe was quaking in every limb--"ruffian, sir! I shall have satisfactionfor this, sir, you may depend upon it."

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 14
author: Various
snippet: "A villain, did you say, Cressingham?" repeated Raeburn, his lips paleand quivering as he spoke.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 14
author: Various
snippet: Having by no means any wish to renew the conversation, Raeburn availedhimself of the opportunity presented by the woman's retiring into thehouse, to sneak off, which he did, and joined his friend Cressingham,who was waiting for him at a little distance.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 14
author: Various
snippet: "What!" exclaimed Raeburn, in a tone of voice startling from itshollowness, and becoming deadly pale; his mean and dastardly soulinstantly sinking under the weight of guilt with which he felt thisdreadful intelligence burdening it.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 14
author: Various
snippet: That evening, the first of her arrival, Raeburn, contrary to hispromise, did not again visit her; but Cressingham came in his place,and dreadful was the result of this unwelcome visit on the poor girl'sframe.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 14
author: Various
snippet: Fanny's luggage was placed in it, and she, Raeburn, andCressingham, were forthwith rowed on shore, where, the moment theylanded, the latter, after whispering something into Raeburn's ear, andoffering some ineffectual attempts at making his peace with MissRutherford, left them.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 14
author: Various
snippet: When Cressingham had taken up the position described, and had begun thenauseous badinage alluded to, Raeburn, on some trifling pretence, leftthe cabin and went on deck.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 14
author: Various
snippet: In the work, too,in which she was employed, be it observed, Raeburn did not offer her thesmallest assistance, but continued walking up and down the cabin,whistling carelessly, and looking at the prints with which the wallswere hung.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 14
author: Various
snippet: On the ship's arrival at Calcutta, which she reached in safety and indue course of time, amongst the first persons who came on board of herwere Raeburn and Cressingham.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 14
author: Various
snippet: Raeburn and Cressingham--the latter, we needhardly say, being nearly as unprincipled as the former--having come tothe understanding which we have just detailed, Raeburn insisted thattheir bargain should be expressed on paper; that is, that Cressinghamshould bind himself by a written document to fulfil his part of thetransaction--in other words, should bind himself to pay the L5000 on theday Fanny became his wife; although with what face he could produce sucha document in a court of justice to enforce his claim, in the event ofCressingham evading it, it certainly is not easy to conceive.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 14
author: Various
snippet: "Umph!" ejaculated Raeburn, "that wouldn't be altogether so convenientjust now.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 14
author: Various
snippet: "Well, hang me if she an't a devilish pretty creature that, after all!"said Tom Cressingham to Raeburn, as they one day sat alone smoking theirhookahs in the apartment in which Fanny's portrait hung, and on which hewas listlessly gazing.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 14
author: Various
snippet: Fanny's father and brothers, therefore, were perfectly aware of theattachment alluded to; and although, of course, the marriage of theparties was a thing not to be thought of in their present circumstances,yet, as Henry was likely soon to obtain a lucrative situation in India,it was a very probable and very desirable contingency; and with thisprospective consideration, Fanny's father did not disapprove of herchoice, as young Raeburn was otherwise, by birth and education, aperfectly eligible match for his daughter.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 14
author: Various
snippet: "Yes, sir, Raeburn is no more--his villanous career is ended.

By all that'ssacred, I will!" At this moment, Raeburn rushed to the window, with theview of calling for assistance; and one supplicatory cry, which,however, was unattended to, he did emit.

title: Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott, Volume 6
author: Lockhart, J. G. (John Gibson)
snippet: I hesitate a little about Raeburn, unless your Grace is     quite determined.

title: Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott, Volume 6
author: Lockhart, J. G. (John Gibson)
snippet: Raeburn should be warned that I am as well acquainted with my friend'shands and arms as with his nose--and Vandyke was of my opinion.

title: Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott, Volume 6
author: Lockhart, J. G. (John Gibson)
snippet: But the malady had gone too far to bearrested by a change of climate; and the letter which he had addressedto Scott, when about to embark at Portsmouth, is endorsed with thesewords: "_The last I ever received from my dear friend the Duke ofBuccleuch.--Alas! alas!_" The principal object of this letter was toremind Scott of his promise to sit to Raeburn for a portrait, to behung up in that favorite residence where the Duke had enjoyed most ofhis society.

title: Noctes ambrosianæ,
author: Wilson, John
snippet: * It is scarcely necessary to go into details respecting painters so well known as Raeburn, Wilkie, and Allan.

snippet: Raeburn and he always keep up our art at the exhibition.

title: Memoirs of the life of Sir Walter Scott,
author: Lockhart, J. G.
snippet: He signified that he would very gladly have that; but took occasion to remind Sir Walter, that the Buccleuch family had not forgot his own old promise to sit to Raeburn for a portrait,  to be hung up at Bowhill.

title: Recollections of a Visit to Glasgow with the British Archæological Associations, August 27th to September 5th, 1888. With notes
author: Lambert, George
snippet: Among them are the portraits by Raeburn ofGeorge Chalmers of Pittencrieff and Provost Low of Fordel,one by Sir Francis Grant of James 8th Earl of Elgin,who was successively Governor-General of Jamaica, Canada,and India, and Plenipotentiary to China; and a fourthportrait by Lawrence of Admiral Sir Andrew Mitchell.

title: Story of a Stolen Heir. A novel
author: Bertram, James Glass.
snippet: " An' what for no, Mr. Lankester ? Doyou think, sir, that there's nae fancy inScotchmen, and that a' that kind o' thing'sleft to you porter-swiUin' fellows o' EngUshmen ? Hae ye forgotten Burns and Scott,sir; or Sir David Wilkie, sir; or Mr.Hogg, the Ettrick Shepherd, sir ; or Raeburn, or Roberts, or Allan, and the rest,sir—Chalmers among them—that has conferred honour on oor country ? 'Deed, butyere no blate, my braw lad."
